hints_raw: It might help to draw a picture.
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
A picture is included below.

Imagine yourself standing on the x-axis at x=-1 looking towards the rotated object. This top down view (the circles in the picture) show that what we are doing is taking a cylinder of radius 1 and height \(\pi\), and subtracting from it the shape that we get from removing the inner shape of radius \((1-\sin(x))^{2}\). This gives the volume to be

\(V = \int_{0}^{\pi} \pi(1^{2} - (1-\sin(x))^{2}) \, dx = \pi\int_{0}^{\pi}(2\sin(x) -\sin^{2}(x)) \, dx\)

completing the question.
sols_latex:
A picture is included below.

Imagine yourself standing on the \emph{x}-axis at \emph{x}=-1 looking
towards the rotated object. This top down view (the circles in the
picture) show that what we are doing is taking a cylinder of radius 1
and height $\pi$, and subtracting from it the shape that we get from
removing the inner shape of radius $(1-\sin(x))^{2}$. This gives the
volume to be

$V = \int_{0}^{\pi} \pi(1^{2} - (1-\sin(x))^{2}) \, dx = \pi\int_{0}^{\pi}(2\sin(x) -\sin^{2}(x)) \, dx$

completing the question.

sols_raw:
A picture is included below.

Imagine yourself standing on the ''x''-axis at ''x''=-1 looking towards the rotated object. This top down view (the circles in the picture) show that what we are doing is taking a cylinder of radius 1 and height <math>\pi</math>, and subtracting from it the shape that we get from removing the inner shape of radius <math> (1-\sin(x))^{2} </math>. This gives the volume to be

<math>
V = \int_{0}^{\pi} \pi(1^{2} - (1-\sin(x))^{2}) \, dx = \pi\int_{0}^{\pi}(2\sin(x) -\sin^{2}(x)) \, dx
</math>

completing the question.

statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

Set up, but do not evaluate, a definite integral for the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region between \(y=0\) and \(y = \sin x\) for \(0 \leq x \leq \pi\) about the line \(y = 1\).
statement_latex:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

Set up, but do not evaluate, a definite integral for the volume of the
solid obtained by rotating the region between $y=0$ and $y = \sin x$ for
$0 \leq x \leq \pi$ about the line $y = 1$.
statement_raw:
<b> Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required. </b>

Set up, but do not evaluate, a definite integral for the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region between <math> y=0 </math> and <math> y = \sin x </math> for <math> 0 \leq x \leq \pi </math> about the line <math> y = 1 </math>.
